about.summary: PyQAlloy is a tool for detection of abnormal data in alloy datasets (and other chemical spaces), allowing removal of hard-to-find erros in the data which often introduce systematic errors throwing off machine learning and researchers alike. Its development is a part of ULTERA Project carried under the DOE ARPA-E ULTIMATE program that aims to develop a new generation of materials for turbine blades and related applications.

PyQAlloy is a tool for detection of abnormal data in alloy datasets (and other chemical spaces), allowing removal of hard-to-find erros in the data which often introduce systematic errors throwing off machine learning and researchers alike. Its development is a part of ULTERA Project carried under the DOE ARPA-E ULTIMATE program that aims to develop a new generation of materials for turbine blades and related applications.

name: pyqalloy
raw_meta_yaml:
{% set name = "pyqalloy" %}
{% set version = "0.3.7" %}

package:
  name: {{ name|lower }}
  version: {{ version }}

source:
  url: https://pypi.io/packages/source/{{ name[0] }}/{{ name }}/pyqalloy-{{ version }}.tar.gz
  sha256: be21569e0fcdf40fa1cb1f630ae54f1d9668b9c950ca95c61ef8935021b13e1d

build:
  noarch: python
  script: {{ PYTHON }} -m pip install . -vv --no-deps --no-build-isolation
  number: 0

requirements:
  host:
    - python >=3.9
    - setuptools >=61.0
    - setuptools-scm
    - pip
  run:
    - montydb >=2.5.2
    - python >=3.9
    - pymatgen >=2022.1.9
    - numpy >=1.22.0
    - tqdm >=4.63.0
    - natsort >=8.0.0
    - pymongo >=4.2
    - pysmartdl >=1.3.4
    - dnspython
    - scikit-learn
    - plotly
    - xlsxwriter
    - python-kaleido

test:
  imports:
    - pyqalloy
  commands:
    - pip check
  requires:
    - pip

about:
  home: https://github.com/PhasesResearchLab/PyQAlloy
  summary: PyQAlloy is a tool for detection of abnormal data in alloy datasets (and other chemical spaces), allowing removal of hard-to-find erros in the data which often introduce systematic errors throwing off machine learning and researchers alike. Its development is a part of ULTERA Project carried under the DOE ARPA-E
    ULTIMATE program that aims to develop a new generation of materials for turbine blades and related applications.
  license: MIT
  license_file: LICENSE

extra:
  recipe-maintainers:
    - amkrajewski
    - jan-janssen
